title: 112_hr4108
content:
The "Clean Energy Jobs Act of 2012" is also known as the Act. It increases and extends the credit for qualifying advanced energy projects. The "Clean Energy Jobs Act of 2012" amends section 48C of the Internal Revenue Code to establish a program for awarding certifications for qualified investments in advanced energy projects. The total amount of credits allocated under this program cannot exceed $5 billion. The amendment sets a limit of $5 billion for the program described in subparagraph (A), with rules similar to paragraphs (2), (3), (4), and (5) applying. Applicants have 2 years from program establishment to submit applications. The effective date of the amendment is the enactment date of the Act. Subtitle A of Title II focuses on closing tax loopholes for major integrated oil companies, specifically modifying foreign tax credit rules. This includes changes for companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Subtitle A of Title II addresses tax loopholes for major integrated oil companies, including adjustments to foreign tax credit rules for dual capacity taxpayers, such as major integrated oil companies. This involves special rules regarding payments to foreign countries or U.S. possessions that do not impose a generally applicable income tax. The text discusses adjustments to foreign tax credit rules for dual capacity taxpayers, specifically those related to payments made to foreign countries or U.S. possessions without a generally applicable income tax. A dual capacity taxpayer is defined as a person in a foreign country or U.S. possession who meets certain criteria. The text discusses adjustments to foreign tax credit rules for dual capacity taxpayers, specifically related to receiving economic benefits from a foreign country or possession subject to a levy. The term "generally applicable income tax" is defined as an income tax imposed on income derived from a trade or business within a foreign country or possession. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States. SEC. 202. LIMITATION ON SECTION 199 DEDUCTION ATTRIBUTABLE TO OIL, NATURAL GAS, OR PRIMARY PRODUCTS THEREOF. The amendment denies the deduction for certain oil and gas income for major integrated oil companies starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 203 amends the Internal Revenue Code to limit deductions for intangible drilling and development costs for major integrated oil companies. The amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. SEC. 204 limits the percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells. SEC. 204 limits the percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells for major integrated oil companies, with the allowance being zero for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 205 limits the deduction for tertiary injectants. SEC. 205 limits the deduction for tertiary injectants for major integrated oil companies, with the amendment applying to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 211 repeals royalty relief for outer continental shelf deep water and deep gas leases. The Secretary of the Interior is no longer required to provide royalty relief starting from the first lease sale after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 221 focuses on deficit reduction. Subtitle C--Miscellaneous

SEC. 221. DEFICIT REDUCTION.

The savings from this Act and its amendments will be used for Federal budget deficit reduction or reducing the Federal debt as deemed appropriate by the Secretary of the Treasury.

SEC. 222. BUDGETARY EFFECTS.

The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined in compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
